Articles.Content:
Build as small a ship as possible to go from Kerbal to the Sun.

Requirements:

Stock only

Get close enough to sun to be torn apart by tidal forces and/or trigger a bug like divide by zero (NaN), negative velocity, etc.

Screenshots

Scoring priority(on ground):

Fewest Engines(liquid and solid included)

Tiebreak: Least fuel at liftoff

Tiebreak 2: lowest gross mass

My current record so far: 7 engines 44 fuel tanks, 135.5 units mass. (will post the screenshots later, but I think I have room to improve my staging.)

I suspect you\'re doing a Hohmann descent, where you leave out the rear of Kerbin\'s SOI, and try to decelerate directly to sundive?

If you\'re willing to spend a couple real-time hours flying the mission, you can cut the required Delta-V by more than half by doing a bi-elliptic transfer. Leave out the front of the SOI into a fairly-elliptical orbit, then slow down at apoapsis.

Six Shot 3 is a poorly designed ship, and could be improved handily, and and I made some poor piloting decisions in the video.

But it sundives on 10 engines and 22 liquid-fuel tanks, plus 1 RCS tank. If I\'d flown it better, I wouldn\'t have even needed the RCS fuel. Basically, anything that can reach solar escape velocity can sundive, if you\'re willing to take the long way around.

I got 'close enough' with a stripped-down version of my stock Mun lander. It has 7 LFEs and 20 fuel tanks. By 'close enough', I mean almost to 700 million km and the altimeter malfunctioned. (See the attached video. After periapsis, the altimeter kept decreasing, even though vertical speed was positive. I used time warp more than 2x, everything worked normally.)

The bi-elliptic technique is intriguing! I really don\'t understand why it works. It seems to me this requires extra energy to climb farther away from Kerbol, and then backtrack.

My trick is the liquid boosters feed fuel to the lander stage, and all engines run at liftoff. All I did was leave Kerbin\'s SOI from the trailing side.

But I prefer to call it 'sun dive'. It helps if your ship is all black, with black controls and black indicators that light up black on black.

It works because for any orbital radius, Escape Velocity is always sqrt(2)*Orbital Velocity, so when starting from a circular orbit, The delta-V you need to escape is only 41.4% that of what you need to drop straight down. The farther out your apoapsis, the slower you wind up moving out there, and the less delta-V you need at that distance to raise or lower your periapsis.

Fun fact: Starting from a circular orbit around an object of radius R, your orbital radius must be less than 4.8 R for the delta-V change necessary to hit the object to be less than the delta-V to escape the object.

This is the Triplicate.

19 fuel tanks, 7 liquid fuel engines

I wound up putting it into this orbit:

I actually had to slow it down a bit to get it into that orbit; I exited Kerbin\'s SOI moving faster than solar escape velocity. Quick calculations showed that at apoapsis, the spacecraft would be moving at 200 m/s. It would also take 10,000 game days to get there. Much as I enjoy the game, I don\'t enjoy it enough to leave it running at 10,000x speed for two real days to complete the course.

And because of that slowdown, I was left with a sliver of fuel in the tank.

Which ultimately turned out to be barely enough decelerate the craft by the 200 m/s to sundive, had I decided to go through with it.
